Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:The emergence of novel regeneration niches- Forecasting tree species recruitment dynamics in a time of change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Forests are the natural vegetation of about half of the U.S., and an important, current goal in ecology is to understand how changes in climate affect the structure and composition of forests. This project will approach this goal by focusing on a critical aspect of forest dynamics -- the recruitment of new trees into the forest as seedlings. To make the research most relevant to current conditions, the project will consider not just effects of climate, but how these may interact with effects from the fragmentation of forests and from the presence of introduced, invasive species. Research will combine field-based, observational, and experimental work with statistical analyses and modeling of the recruitment dynamics of several dominant tree species in the temperate deciduous forests of eastern North America, using sites from northern to southern Michigan. The results will lay a foundation for forecasting the future structure and composition of these forests.

Forests are a major natural resource for the nation. To manage them sustainably, policy makers and land users need to be able to plan for the likely complicating effects of climate change. The results from this project will give managers information about the potential of important forest trees to maintain stable populations under a range of management regimes. The project also includes an educational component. Methods and outcomes of the research will be disseminated in educational materials for university and K-12 students to foster scientific literacy about scientific models that describe and predict the impacts of climate change on forests.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work carried as part of this project is guided by the societal need to forecast the response of forest organisms, populations, communities and ecosystems to global change. In particular, this research focused on forecasts at temporal and spatial scales that can inform forest related management practices and policy. The experimental and observational work carried out was aimed at developing the knowledge necessary to predict organisms’ responses to the novel environments created by global change. The outcomes of this work have resulted in enhanced model realism, explanatory insight and predictive power, all of which yield information that can inform management decisions and optimize conservation, restoration and sustainable practice efforts for a wide range of forest ecosystems, varying from natural areas to tree plantations and urban vegetation.

This research has been particularly novel in the sense that it experimentally evaluated the in situ adaptation of local dominant tree species and the migratory potential of southern tree species to global warming. So far our results have identified species that will thrive, and some that will not, under the predicted environments, and have also revealed some of the complex biotic interactions that could shape tree range expansion. To forecast tree species recruitment dynamics beyond the range of environmental conditions individuals have been exposed to, we have worked on linking physiological performance over the growing season with demographic performance over the years. This integration of physiological and demographic data has the potential to generate much more accurate forecasts of future performance since they are based on mechanisms and not on correlations.

Another unique approach of our research is that we have studied ecological processes in the context of not only a changing climate, but also of the landscape configuration characteristic of the region, levels of pollution and of introduced harmful species. This work takes into consideration that forest ecosystems are not responding in isolation to each of these factors but that it is rather their synergistic, antagonistic or additive effects that exert an influence on forests. Findings from this work have revealed differential effects of fragmentation, urbanization, pollution and invasions among tree species, indicating the potential for substantial shifts along the landscape in forests assemblages and in the ecosystem services they provide.

We have produced data, parameter estimates, models and forecasts that constitute the basis for process-based modeling, and therefore, contributes to the prediction of future forest dynamics at the temporal and spatial scales that can inform sustainable management and restoration and conservation practices.
